title: Cornel Drăgușin
text:
Cornel Drăgușin (26 March 1926 – 10 October 2021) was a Romanian <a href="Association%20football">football</a> manager who coached the national teams of Iraq, Syria and Romania. He was director of the <a href="Romanian%20Football%20Federation">Romanian FA</a> coaching school from 1990 to 2002, until being replaced by <a href="Mircea%20R%C4%83dulescu">Mircea Rădulescu</a>.
Managerial career.
Drăgușin had a short stint as football player, and eventually became a coach at the age of 25. He served as a youth coach with <a href="CSA%20Steaua%20Bucure%C8%99ti%20%28football%29">Steaua Bucharest</a> from 1950 to 1953. He then managed the youth team of <a href="AFC%20Progresul%20Bucure%C8%99ti">Progresul Bucuresti</a>, where he won the national youth championship in 1954, before moving up to the reserves and finally the A team, with whom he was runner-up in the <a href="Romanian%20Cup">Romanian Cup</a> during the 1957–58 season. After two years, he was named assistant coach being part of the Progresul squad that won the Romanian Cup in 1960.
In 1962, the <a href="Iraq%20Football%20Association">Iraq Football Association</a> opted for a foreign coach from the <a href="Eastern%20Bloc">Eastern Bloc</a>, and appointed the Romanian manager as head coach of the <a href="Iraq%20national%20football%20team">Iraq national team</a>. He was the first foreign coach of Iraq and at the beginning of his period there, he was supervised by <a href="colonel">colonel</a> <a href="Abdul%20Salam%20Arif">Abdul Salam Arif</a> who later became the country's president.
After his return from Iraq in 1963, Drăgușin joined Progresul again with coach <a href="Dinc%C4%83%20Schileru">Dincă Schileru</a> for the <a href="1963%E2%80%9364%20Divizia%20A">1963–64</a> season, before taking charge of the <a href="Syria%20national%20football%20team">Syrian national team</a> in 1965. Upon his return, the Romanian FA appointed Drăgușin as manager of the Romania under–23 side for a tournament in <a href="Central%20Africa">Central Africa</a>. In 1967, he returned to Progresul for a third spell until 1969, before moving to Steaua Bucharest as assistant manager.
In 1969, he spent nearly two months visiting some of the top English clubs including <a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.">Manchester United</a>, <a href="Chelsea%20F.C.">Chelsea</a> and <a href="Arsenal%20F.C.">Arsenal</a>. On his return, he wrote a book, "În patria fotbalului – In Football's Homeland" released in 1970.
In November 1970, he was recruited by the <a href="Romanian%20Football%20Federation">Romanian Football Federation</a>, for whom he worked until 2002. During that time, he coached the <a href="Romania%20national%20football%20team">Romanian national team</a>, the Under–23, Under–21 sides and the Olympic team. Between 1986 and 1990, he was <a href="Emerich%20Jenei">Emerich Jenei</a>'s assistant coach at the Romanian national team, which qualified for the <a href="1990%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1990 FIFA World Cup</a> in <a href="Italy">Italy</a>.
Drăgușin was director of the Romanian FA coaching school from 1990 to 2002, a period during which some of best players in Romania obtained their coaching licenses including <a href="Dan%20Petrescu">Dan Petrescu</a>, <a href="Gheorghe%20Hagi">Gheorghe Hagi</a>, <a href="Ilie%20Dumitrescu">Ilie Dumitrescu</a>, <a href="Ioan%20Andone">Ioan Andone</a>, <a href="Ioan%20Sab%C4%83u">Ioan Sabău</a>, <a href="Mircea%20Rednic">Mircea Rednic</a>, <a href="Gavril%20Balint">Gavril Balint</a> and <a href="Dorinel%20Munteanu">Dorinel Munteanu</a>.
